--- In gladiator@y..., "Tom Tildrum" <Tevildo@h...> wrote:
> Call me paranoid, but in my case I think the chain lightning 
freeze-up is 
> caused by the amount of memory allocated to running Gladiator. 
Sometimes 
> I'll have other programs running in the background and I can chain 
fifty 
> guys with no problem; sometimes I run it totally by itself from DOS 
and it 
> takes half an hour for the lightning to cycle through fifteen guys. 
I don't 
> have the fastest computer, but it shouldn't be crippled by something 
like 
> that.

Hmm.  How do you suggest we test this theory?


> Something I've noticed: one of the only other things that will slow 
down 
> Gladiator is having a whole hell of a lot of elemental fire on the 
screen. 
> But that's ONLY if the fire is on the screen where you can see it. 
Once you 
> stop sunbursting and the flames reach the edge of the visible field 
> everything speeds up again. Usually this lag isn't significant, but 
it's 
> noticeable.

Personally, I would never use chain-lightning if I have summoned 
elementals.  Sometimes, flames from starbursting reach the ends of the 
scenario.  Any, either I summon lots of fire elementals (I don't mean 
a dozen, I mean mnore like thirty or more) or I use chain lightning.  
Summoning fire elementals is far more efficient as far as using the 
least amount of magic energy compared to summong chain-lightning.

 
> Half-classes made by merging two preexisting characters? How do you 
propose 
> to make that thematic? "The orc tears viciously into the druid, 
devouring 
> his flesh and gaining his skills!" or "After undergoing horrific 
operations, 
> the Archer finally healed... his old skeleton entirely removed and 
replaced 
> with the reanimated skeleton of a dead man." or "The thief 
successfully 
> stole the archmage's staff and cloak." I don't see how this could 
reasonably 
> be introduced, but I'm open to suggestions.

I actually I'd prefer the idea of the two characters exchanging 
abilities rather than merge to become a new character.  Accomplishing 
this would be something like a mage saying to the characters "I bid 
thee from henceforth share abilities."  120 halfings isn't quite 
right.  The total number of halfings would equal the total number of 
characters times the sum of the total number of characters and -1.  Of 
course, you wouldn't allow a character to share abilities with the 
character it can be promoted to, so that limits a few more.
